title: khashoggi disappearance us secretary of state mike pompeo heads to in riyadh
story: The renowned journalist has not been seen since entering the building almost two weeks ago.Speaking on Monday, Donald Trump said the Saudi leader King Salman denied "any knowledge of whatever may have happened" during a phone call.But the US president also said "rogue killers" could be behind the disappearance and that King Salman had told him Saudi Arabia is "working closely with Turkey to find answers". Speaking to reporters as he set off for Florida from the White House, President Trump said he did not "want to get" into King Salmans mind, but added: "It sounded to me like maybe these could have been rogue killers."Reports in the US media suggest that Saudi officials are set to admit that Mr Khashoggi was killed during an interrogation that went wrong, but neither King Salman, or his son and power behind the throne, Crown Prince Mohammed, had ordered Mr Khashoggis death. title: what may happen in critical week for brexit and theresa may
story: The latest British proposals for the Northern Irish "backstop" - the main sticking point in the negotiations - have not been published, but compromise on both sides will be required.If a way forward is found, the withdrawal agreement could be finalised on Thursday, signed at a special EU summit next month and voted on by Parliament at the end of November.Then there is just the small matter of our future relationship with the EU to be worked out. :: The cabinet revoltThe Brexit big beasts are no longer in Mrs Mays cabinet and are openly on the prowl, trying to stir up a mutiny against the prime ministers plans.Former foreign secretary Boris Johnson wrote on Monday that Mrs May must "stand up to the EU bullies" or face humiliation.Former Brexit secretary David Davis called on Sunday for ministers to "exert their collective authority" against Mrs Mays Chequers proposals.Cabinet ministers on "resignation watch" are Brexiteers who have been careful to insist they are supporting the prime minister rather than her plan - Penny Mordaunt, spoken of as a future party leader Esther McVey the welfare secretary, and Andrea Leadsom, the leader of the house. title: theresa address eu leaders brussels
story: NewsTheresa May will address EU leaders at Brussels summit - but doesnt get to stay for dinnerThere wont be a place set for the Prime Minister at the table as the remaining members chew over the future of the EUShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsAwkward "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May has been invited to speak to the  EU leaders at a dinner in Brussels - but shell have to leave before they serve the starters. The Prime Minister is expected to give an update to the leaders of the remaining member states as they sit down for a meal on Wednesday. But they wont have a place set for her, and its understood shell depart the gathering before they dine. The Prime Ministers spokesman said: The PM has accepted an invitation from President Tusk to provide an update on the Brexit negotiations on Wednesday evening. This will take place in advance of a dinner discussion on Brexit by the  other member states.  European Council President Donald Tusk said earlier that the  states remaining in the bloc after Britain leaves must be ready for a no-deal Brexit, a scenario he said was more likely than ever before. With less than six months to go before Britains departure, talks stalled at the weekend over how to ensure there is noto a hard border between the British province of Northern Ireland and EU-member Ireland. Tusk said all parties must do their best to reach a deal, adding that he had invited British Prime Minister Theresa May to address her  EU peers on Brexit on Wednesday evening, the first day of a two-day summit of EU leaders he will chair.  The fact that we are preparing for a no-deal scenario must not, under any circumstances, lead us away from making every effort to reach the best agreement possible ... Let us not give up, Tusk said in an invitation letter to the summit. Later at , we will decide on how to take the negotiations forward, on the basis of a recommendation by our chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, Tusk said in the letter. It has proven to be more complicated than some may have expected. We should nevertheless remain hopeful and determined, as there is good will to continue these talks on both sides, he said.

title: theresa faces showdown pizza plot
story: NewsopinionTheresa May faces showdown with "Pizza plot" Cabinet ministers: Mirror Politics morning briefingThe Prime Minister is looking increasingly isolated as Cabinet ministers plot over pizza how to thwart BrexitShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsopinionTheresa May is loooking increasingly isolated "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Last night eight cabinet ministers met over pizza to discuss how to thwart Theresa May’s Brexit plans .You could describe this as a scintillating piece of insider politics. Or you could view it as an act of indulgence by people charged with leading our country through the most important negotiations undertaken in more than seven decades. Either way, it is further proof that the Conservatives’s self interest has always taken precedence over the national interest when it comes to Brexit. Brazenly holding a Cabinet within the Cabinet is not just taking the pizza out of Theresa May. It shows a contempt for those who expect ministers to show some collective responsibility at a key moment in the negotiations. These same ministers will smile for the cameras as they head to No  this morning for a Cabinet meeting that will be dominated by Brexit. Mrs May’s isolation was underlined when she gave her statement to the Commons yesterday.Her tone was noticeably more conciliatory than the plastic Britannia act after the Salzburg debacle. What was less clear was whom the intended audience was.At first it appeared she was trying to buy time from the Tory Brexiteers by recognising their concerns over a lack of an end date to any backstop .This was, she claimed, an insurance to an insurance policy which she hoped never to use. But Conservative eurosceptics quickly smelt a rat and peppered the PM with questions on,the backstop were to be used, would it be time-limited. Mrs May ducked these questions but then gave the game away in answer to an excellent question from Labour’s Pat McFadden. The backstop would be there “for the time until the future relationship can come into place”, she replied. Incidentally, she also used her answer to rule out any Canada-style trade deal, further angering the Tory Brexiteers.

story: NewsTheresa Mays boast that shes ended austerity exposed as a sham by expertsThe Institute for Fiscal Studies said she would need to magic up a massive £billion a year just to achieve a “minimal definition” of ending austerityShareByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video pm-theresa-promises-end-austerity-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May’s boast that she has ended austerity is a sham, experts warn today. The Prime Minister declared that years of cruel Tory cuts were over in her conference speech this month - and promised voters that “better days” lie ahead. But the Institute for Fiscal Studies said she would need to magic up a massive poundbillion a year just to achieve a “minimal definition” of ending austerity. And evenshe achieved the impossible that would still leave a devastating poundbillion worth of savage cuts to social security. Ahead of the Budget at the end of this month, the IFS also said Mrs May’s boast of ending austerity was “incompatible” with Philip Hammond’s vow to balance the books by his mid-s target.  The IFS said that in order to find an extra poundbillion the Chancellor would have to increase taxes the equivalent of one penny on income tax, National Insurance and VAT. Its report also said there will be “virtually no Brexit idend” to relieve spending pressure on Mr Hammond. Even without taking into account the likely hit to tax revenues following Brexit, the Treasury can expect only a “modest” poundbillion-a-year saving on EU contributions by  . This figure would “easily” be outweighed by additional spending on bureaucracy, such as new border guards, experts said. Unless economic growth is much better than expected, Mr Hammond will face the choice between “substantial” tax hikes or ditching his target of balancing the books by the mid-s. If the Chancellor chooses to fund the end of austerity by raising taxes by % of national income, this would bring the overall tax burden close to its highest level since the end of the Second World War - though it would still be in the middle of the range for developed industrial countries. Even poundbillion of tax increases by   would be enough only to meet existing commitments on additional funding for health, defence and aid - including the the first three years of the five-year poundbillion boost promised to the NHS - while halting real-terms cuts in other areas, said the respected economic think tank.  And this would still leave social security cuts totalling poundbillion to work their way through the system. Describing this goal as “a minimal definition of the end of austerity”, the IFS warned: “Unless there are substantial tax rises, or much-better-than-expected economic growth, the Prime Minister’s aim of ‘ending austerity’ is unlikely to be compatible with the Chancellor’s aim of balancing the books by the mid-s.” This leaves Mr Hammond with “the toughest of circles to square” in his October  Budget and next year’s Spending Review, said IFS director Paul Johnson. The IFS found that the Government has already committed to poundbillion of additional spending on health, defence and aid between   and  . To end austerity, it would also have to halt poundbillion worth of cuts to day-to-day spending in other departments planned for next year, along with a further poundbillion pencilled in for the years to  . Mr Hammond could find this poundbillion sum by hiking every rate of income tax, all National Insurance contributions and the main rate of VAT by p each, said the report. But it also set out a series of alternative tax hikes to target the pain on better-off members of the older generation, including:Ending the practice of writing off Capital Gains Tax on assets in a deceased person’s estate, estimated in  to cost poundmillion a year Abolition of Entrepreneurs Relief, which cost pound.billion in   Charging employee National Insurance contributions on those over state pension age, raising around pound.billion Reforming the “indefensibly generous” treatment of pension pots bequeathed after death, which are not subject to taxthe holder dies before the age of  Reforming council tax so bills are proportional to the value of a property, with a potential poundbillion a year raisedrates on the top four bands were doubled.Mr Johnson said Mr Hammond’s tax and spend choices for the next spending review period, beginning in , will be “the biggest non-Brexit-related decision this Chancellor will make”. “He has a big choice. He could end austerity, as the Prime Minister has suggested. “But even on a limited definition of what that might mean would imply spending poundbillion a year more than currently planned by the end of the Parliament.

story: NewsUniversal Credit set for major climbdown by the Tories reveals leaked documentIt comes after Tory Esther McVey confirmed she will migrate no more than , existing claimants on to the benefit until mid-ShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsMore than , people have signed the Mirrors petition to halt the rollout "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe government is planning a major climbdown over Universal Credit, a leaked document has revealed. It comes hours after Tory welfare chief Esther McVey confirmed she will migrate no more than , existing claimants on to the benefit until mid-. Her confession suggests the vast majority of the UKs .million existing benefit claimants will not begin so-called managed migration until then. Now the BBC reports this move will extend UCs estimated finish date from March  to December , the ninth delay to the rollout. And a document leaked to the Corporation also reveals a string of measures to offer people more help.Hard-up families could now get higher transition payments and lower loan repayments after UC drove desperate people to rent arrears, food banks and prostitution.But crucially, there is NO mention of a halt to the rollout or any change to the taper rate - a core problem with the hated policy. Universal Credit is driving women to prostitution says MP Frank Field in astonishing plea to Esther McVeyInstead, according to the document obtained by the BBC, government officials plan to:Continue paying income support, ESA and jobseekers allowance for two weeks after someone makes a UC claim Reduce deductions when some is paying back an advance loan from % to % of monthly benefit Give more help to the self-employed after warnings the policy will force struggling firms to close altogether.The changes would reportedly cost hundreds of millions of pounds . But an extract from the document also warns the changes might not even be possible.We can currently offer no assurance that ultimately these proposals will prove to be deliverable, can survive legal challenges where they can be delivered, and do not invite new political criticism by generating new policy issues, it says, according to the BBC. Critics are likely to say the measures - which have emerged a year after a separate pound.bn package of tweaks - are not enough. There is no commitment to halt the rollout, and no mention in the BBCs report of the taper rate. Universal Credit is handed over in one payment, which tapers away by p for every extra pound people earn above pound a month. Critics have complained that this is too steep and leaves families worse off. Citizens Advice chief executive Gillian Guy said the leaked measures could reduce” hardship. But she warned: “These measures alone will not solve all of the problems. The government must make changes to ensure no one is left without enough to get by.” Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary Margaret Greenwood said: “The Government must stop the roll out of Universal Credit immediately. We need urgent answers from Esther McVey about whats going on and what action the Government will take to tackle the many flaws in the system. Department for Work and Pensionssources did not deny the end date - estimated as March  by the National Audit Office just months ago - could become December , saying only it would be in . A DWP source insisted the managed migration of .million claimants would still begin in July .  But they conceded the phasing of that migration was open to change - and a spokesman confirmed the department would work with a maximum of , people in the first year. Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey, who last week admitted some UC claimants will be worse off, has repeatedly said she was looking at further changes to the system. Yesterday she told MPs: Under the process of managed migration, the roll-out will be slow and measured. It will start not in January , but later in the year. For a further year we will be learning as we go with a small amount of people - maybe , - to ensure that the system is right. More than , people have signed the Mirrors petition to halt the rollout. The Mirror are demanding a halt to the expansion of Universal Credit and for a review to take place. We say there are three options:Redesign UC to be fit for purpose Axe it in favour of the old systemUC is unfixable Introduce a brand new systemSign our petition to stop the rollout of Universal Credit across Britain and to replace it with a fairer system by signing our petition. A DWP spokeswoman confirmed: “We have long said that we will take a slow and measured approach to managed migration. This will not begin in January , but later in the year, after a period of preparation. For a further year we will then begin migration working with a maximum of , people, continuing with our ‘test and learn’ approach. This is to ensure the system is working well for claimants and to make any necessary adaptions as we go.” The spokeswoman added: “We will publish full plans for the next stage of Universal Credit rollout, including managed migration, in due course. Anything before that point is speculation and we do not comment on leaks.

title: coca cola christmas truck rumours
story: NewsCoca-Cola Christmas truck rumours spreading on social media arent true - heres whyThe Coca-Cola truck is hugely popular as Christmas festivities roll around - but heres why you should be wary of fake events on FacebookShareCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer:,  OCT NewsHolidays are coming... "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email People say that the festive season dont really start until you see Coca-Colas catchy holidays are coming Christmas advert on TV.The drinks companys annual truck tour is also hugely popular - last year the tour started in November at hit up  locations around the UK. Now Coca-Cola truck tour events are already starting to crop up on Facebook, indicating that the tour is stopping in Liverpool, Nottingham, Leicester and dozens of other cities. Social media users need to be wary of these events - as it turns out that theyre fake. Nottinghamshire Live reported that over , Facebook users acknowledged the Nottingham event by ticking that they are interested in going.The fake Nottingham event is listed for December  and December , but no venue details were included. The page announced the fake Nottingham event on October  and said in the Facebook post: The Coca Cola Truck Tour is BACK! Join this event to keep up to date with all the info and locations of the Coca Cola truck!  Similar bogus events have been set up for other cities across the UK. Fans of the Christmas spectacular have been fooled by the fraudulent account with the user name of @cocacolaxmas - which is not the Coca-Cola brand. A spokesperson for Coca-Cola has confirmed that the official dates for the Christmas truck tour will be released on November  - so you can expect the genuine dates to appear then.Check out the official Coca-Cola Facebook account for the real details in November.

story: NewsLittle girls hand Meghan Markle two bunches of flowers - leaving snubbed Prince Harry in stitchesAs Finley Blue, four, and six-year-old Dacha Gallagher, both presented their bouquets in Meghans direction, Harry joked: Oh, youre giving them both to herShareCommentsByLucy Clarke-Billings:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video little-girl-leaves-prince-harry-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Duke of Sussex took advantage of opportunities to raise a smile alongside his we during their first overseas tour. The jokes started early as the couple took in Taronga Zoo and Harry opened the Institute of Science and Learning. Finley Blue, four, and six-year-old Dacha Gallagher, both presented their bouquets of traditional flowers in Meghans direction, with Harry joking: Oh, youre giving them both to her. The duke also showed off his sense of humour when the zoos director Cameron Kerr spoke of the ious work the zoo does with pre-school groups, and Harry pointed to the  Youth at the Zoo volunteers aged - in the crowd and pulled a mock confused face. When Mr Kerr appeared to briefly struggle to get out all the syllables in Duke of Sussex and Duchess of Sussex, Harry was on hand to smile and pronounce Sussexes.  He followed this up with a cheery Gday as he spoke at Admiralty House for an afternoon reception hosted by the Governor General Sir Peter Cosgrove and Lady Cosgrove. He thanked the couple for giving their magnicent home over to the Sussexes for the week, before adding We are inviting all our mates in Sydney... Finally, we are both absolutely delighted to be here. We are really impressed to see you serving beer and tea at an afternoon reception in true Aussie style, Harry added. But the humour was not solely being dished out by the duke.  As the couple were preparing to cut the ribbon to open the institute, Meghan appeared to realise she was still holding her coat. She moved towards an aide and a member of the crowd shouted out, Ill look after it for you!, to which Mr Kerr added: You might not get it back! The crowds started to gather more than three hours before the Duke and Duchess of Sussex performed their first overseas walkabout on the forecourt of the Sydney Opera House. Well-wishers brought homemade signs, toys and newspaper clippings as the expecting couple were greeted by hundreds of people and the sunshine.  The good weather was in stark contrast to the grey skies of Monday when Harry and Meghan arrived in the city. The duke and duchess were met with cheers and royal fans craned their necks and held smartphones aloft for a chance to glimpse the pair. Among those in the crowd were sisters Hannah and Francesca Francis,  and . Hannah said: I told my sister we would see Meghan today but I couldnt believe it when she came over to speak to us. She was so nice and friendly and she is so pretty. She was so nice to us and said thank you for coming down to meet her.  Francesca said: We were both super excited to meet Harry and Meghan, I just cant believe we did. Our friends are going on be so jealous, were going to be taking about this forever. Another group of -year-old schoolgirls were not ashamed of skipping school to get the chance to meet the couple. Emerson Yee held up a poster saying, I gave up perfect school attendance to see you. She said: They both said they liked my poster - but they told me not to miss school again!  Four young girls were plucked from the audience and presented bouquets to the couple, including two-year-old Charlotte Collier. Kimberley Mueller, her sister, said: They just came straight up and shook our hands. She took the flowers from the girls and they were just gorgeous, the pair of them. I was shaking with the mums, I was like, Is it normal that Im shaking  It was amazing. We talked about how much they were enjoying Sydney and how theyre going to be back. It was awesome.

story: NewsSimple mistake which could invalidate your car insurance - and millions of drivers might be at riskInsurers are warning that you could find yourself in the situation of having a claim rejectedyou dont tell them of any modications made to your vehicleShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsInsurers are warning of the importance of informing them of modications made to your car"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A simple mistake could invalidate your car insurance - and millions of drivers are potentially at risk.Drivers could have modications on their car they are simply not aware of, but failure to tell insurers of any modications could invalidate the insurance, experts say.Any modications to your car , which aren’t classed as factory standard - even aesthetic changes such as specialist paintwork or decals - will affect the cost of replacing your vehicle should it be damaged or stolen.Anything classed as non-standard on the car is classed as a modication. Research has found that only . percent of drivers are claiming to have modications on their vehicle, suggesting drivers simply may not be declaring any added extras. GoCompare are warning motorists to double check what the factory standard is for your cars model, and let insurers know of any changes made.  Matt Oliver, spokesperson for GoCompare car insurance, said: “While modications may ring bells of the bygone boy racer, it’s worth remembering that insurers don’t just class body kits, exhaust systems or suspension changes as vehicle modications. “The average used car buyer could find there are modications they’re simply not aware of. Typically, modications are anything which isn’t standard on a car, which could include alloy wheels, a satellite navigation system or even tinted windows – so it’s always worth checking what the factory standard is for your model of car to avoid landing in hot water when it comes to making a claim. “Under two percent of drivers are claiming to have car modications, but we estimate this figure to be much greater, which leaves potentially millions of drivers open to invalidating their insurance and having their claims rejected.  Mr Oliver added: “Dferent insurers have dferent views on what constitutes a modication – so it’s always wise to tell your insurer of changes or additions you make to your vehicle at the time of making them. “Otherwise you could find yourself in the situation of having a claim rejected and possibly your car insurance declared void - that could affect your ability to be insured full stop, and not only for car insurance. “Shop around and look for the best deal that suits you and your car, andin doubt, check the service history for any modication and speak to your insurance provider.”

title: they really two peas pod
story: NewsThey really are two peas in a pod: Hope that tiny twins can find forever home so they can grow up togetherAs National Adoption Week arrives, brothers who were born severely premature and cant stand being apart are still waiting for someone to love themShareCommentsByLaura Connor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video twins-kian-kalan-searching-loving-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTossing and turning in his cot, baby Kian could not sleep. He seemed to be missing twin brother Kalan, who lay  miles away in a hospital incubator with fluid forming on his brain. The tots were born severely premature, leaving them with a chronic lung condition which kept them in intensive care for the first six months of their lives. While Kian had developed into a healthy, happy boy, he was not content without his sibling. Remembering Kalan’s time at Great Ormond Street Hospital in London, the boys’ carer Paulette, , says they couldn’t wait to be reunited. “Kian missed his brother so much,” she smiles. “He would get up in the morning and look over at his cot. “He would start to wake up much earlier, searching around for his brother. It was obvious he really missed him.” Kalan is now out of hospital and the one-year-old twins are playing with their favourite matching toy crocodiles once again. But there is still something missing in their young lives. Kian and Kalan are two of thousands of children waiting to find their for ever home. The twins are living with a foster carer but authorities have taken the unusual step of calling for prospective families to come forward in the hope of finding someone to adopt them. Paulette is desperate for the pair to find a loving new family.  She says: “Children with health problems can find it dficult to find homes and it is harder for twins to find people willing to adopt them together. “But the last thing we would want to do is split Kian and Kalan up. They really are two peas in a pod. “I would say to whoever is considering adopting them, they have had a sad start to le but they really need a home and a family that will nurture and stimulate them. They are very clever, determined and lovable. “It’s important for them to have a home where they can stay for ever.” Kian and Kalan were born in January last year,  weeks premature and weighing just lb oz each. As a result, the non-identical twins developed chronic lung disease and had to spend six months in a London hospital.  While Kian has recovered, Kalan suffered a build-up of fluid on his brain known as post-haemorrhagic hydrocephalus with a subgaleal shunt. It can cause long-term complications, including learning disabilities and memory issues. He will have regular check-ups for the rest of his le. When Paulette, who has two grown-up children, met the boys in hospital, they were still on oxygen in intensive care and taking a lot of medication. “There are still some uncertainties about Kalan’s future due to their premature birth,” she says. “But he is a very gentle and contained character, and content to play by himself. “Although, of course, he loves reading and playing – and fighting – with his brother! “When I walked into the hospital and saw them I knew I had to look after them, they looked so helpless. I spent a week in hospital learning how to give them their medication and getting to know them.” But since they came out of hospital in June last year, Kalan has suffered health issues. Just before Christmas, he was in a hospital for a month after a seizure and developing hydrocephalus. He is now back home and getting better every day.  You can help more kids get a second chance Comment by Damian Hinds, Education Secretary If ever a week had the potential to change lives, it is this one. National Adoption Week is about giving children who have had a tough start in le a second chance. And I can’t think of anything more worthwhile than that. Being a dad to three wonderful children has brought me so much joy. But there are many children who don’t have a family to give them the love and care they need. Right now, there are more than , waiting to be adopted by families, hoping to find the loving and stable home so many of us sometimes take for granted. What we are looking for is a erse mix of prospective adopters from a range of backgrounds, who reflect our rich and vibrant society. It’s great that we have seen the number of children adopted by same-sex couples almost double since . But there is more to be done and I encourage as many people as possible to consider adopting. What kind of person makes a good adoptive parent  You need what any parent needs – to give the child unlimited love, time, patience, understanding and support. You also need to stand up for them, see their positive qualities, even when times may be hard, and support them to live happy, fulfilled childhoods. You don’t need to be rich, all you need is total commitment. There is extra help available for families who need it. Many of these kids will have had a traumatic start in le. The Adoption Support Fund will help pay for therapy for adoptive families and children cared for under a special ship. It has helped thousands since May , backed by poundmillion. If you have thought about adoption, visit firstadoption . This will give you a good understanding of what is involved and you could be one step closer to helping to change a child’s le.

Of course I would love to have kids right now but theres a process that one has to go through and tours like this are great fun, Harry said. Hopefully Im doing all right by myself. It would be great to have someone  next to me to share the pressure, but you know, time will come and whatever happens, happens. Prince Harry is already godfather to a few of his friends children. I think the key to that is to be able to grow up, but also be able to stay in touch with your childhood side, Harry said on being good at the role.  Like Harry, who is known for being at ease with youngsters, Meghan has impressed onlookers with her affectionate nature when meeting children on royal walkabouts. In Birmingham on International Womens Day in , she hugged -year-old Sophie Richards, telling her she could achieve whatever she wanted to achieve, after learning the schoolgirl wanted to become an actress. Meghan also spent time getting to know William and Kates eldest children Prince George and Princess Charlotte in the run-up to her engagement, and was living nearby at Kensington Palace when the family celebrated the arrival of Prince Louis.  The celebrity, who shot to fame playing paralegal Rachel Zane in the American drama Suits, already has two fairy god-daughters.She described the children of her close friend Benita Litt as such in a  post on her since deleted Instagram account, and the girls - Remi and Rylan - were among her bridesmaids at her wedding.During their wedding ceremony, Harry looked tenderly at his bride and smiled when the Dean of Windsor spoke of marriage being the foundation of family le in which children are born and nurtured.  The Duchesss father Thomas Markle said he expected Meghan and Harry would want to try for children soon. He told ITVs Good Morning Britain in an interview a month after the wedding: Shes wanted children for a long time and when she met Harry and she spoke about how much she loves him, theres got to be a child in the making, somewhere soon. Earlier today Kensington Palace confirmed that the Duke and Duchess of Sussex are expecting their first child. In an announcement the palace wrote: Their Royal Highnesses The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are very pleased to announce that The Duchess of Sussex is expecting a baby in the Spring of .

title: uk weather forecast temperatures nosedive
story: NewsUK Weather forecast: Temperatures to nosee amid heavy SNOW this month beginning winter freezeRecord breaking low temperatures could be seen in parts of the country this month, a WeatherAction forecaster has warnedShareCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video fog-frost-risk-temperatures-dip-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTemperatures in the UK are about to nosee amid heavy snowfall before the end of this month, according to reports. Brits could be facing the start of a four month Polar assault with sub zero temperatures until February next year, reports say. And a substantial amount of snow is threatening Scotland, northern and central England. Conditions could be even more extreme than during the Beast from the East earlier this year. Very low temperatures - which could break October records - have been forecast by WeatherAction.  WeatherAction’s Piers Corbyn told the: We are expecting some quite severe snowfall before the end of this month and it will not just be confined to the far north, this could reach parts of the midlands or even further south. This spell of very cold weather looks like bringing substantial snow to a more widespread area of the country than people would necessarily expect at this time of year. We are also forecasting some very low temperatures, we could see the record for October broken this year.  The forecaster blamed changes in the structure of the plasma layer around the sun which will apparently encourage cold air over the North Pole to spill south and towards Europe. This is known as a displaced Polar Vortex. Mr Corbyn predicts an early onset of severe winter - getting more severe from the end of next month. earlier reported that Storm Callum has eased off after claiming the lives of three people. The storm caused travel misery and flooding as rivers burst their banks and power supplies were wiped out for many across western parts over Friday and Saturday, with south Wales the worst-hit region. A man died after a landslide struck on Saturday near the village of Cwmduad in Carmarthenshire, west Wales. The victim, whose age was not given, died at the scene on the A, Dyfed-Powys Police said. The east and south east escaped the storms wrath and enjoyed largely sunny, warm conditions. Donna Nook in Lincolnshire reached .C on Saturday, making it the warmest October day in seven years. In the early hours of tomorrow, clouds and patchy rain will remain over the south-east corner of the UK with a drier, cooler outlook expected for the week.

title: embassys cat pyjama party invitation
story: NewsUS embassys cat pyjama party invitation sent out on email blamed on new member of staffOfficials in Australia blamed the accidental invite on a "training error"ShareCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsDiplomacy at its finest "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEverybody loves a pyjama party, but most people dont expect to receive an invite from a diplomatic institution. The United States embassy in Canberra, Australia, has apologised for sending a fake meeting invitation featuring a cat wearing pyjamas.The email, titled meeting, featured a snap of a tabby cat wearing a Cookie Monster outfit and holding a plate of choc-chip biscuits, according to the Australian Associated Press .Beneath the title, the event read cat pajama-jam and was hosted by the US State Department.  The hilarious mistake also contained a section of Latin and an RSVP button. Its not clear exactly how many recipients there were to the cat pyjama party event. Gavin Sundwall, the public affairs counselor at the US Mission to Australia, chalked the gaffe up to a training error. He said the mistake was made by a new staff member who was testing out our email newsletter .  “Sorry to disappoint those of you who were hoping to attend this cat pajama-jam party,” Sundwall wrote in a light-hearted follow-up email two days later, according to the AAP. But such an event falls well outside our area of expertise. People on social media have found the mistake hilarious. One person tweeted a picture of their cat reading the news story on an Ipad, captioned: Joeys upset that the cat pajama-jam wont be happening.  Some people are adamant that an apology for the gaffe wasnt necessary, with one person writing: Never apologize for a Cat Pajama Jam! Others are simply keen to attend the fake event, with one person writing: I would like to rsvp yes to the cat pajama-jam. The US embassy in New Zealand said it was LOLing at the error in a Twitter post.

title: dundee fans group writes to top officials over referee steven mcleans links to kilmarnock
story: Angry Dundee fans have written to two top refereeing officials over whistler Steven McLean being put in charge of Saturday’s controversial clash with Kilmarnock despite having strong family connections with the Ayrshire club.McLean blundered by awarding the second-half penalty that saw Killie take the three points from the Dens Park clash.And supporters with long memories are unhappy he was handling the proceedings despite his father, Stewart, making over  appearances for the Rugby Parkers between  and .To add to the conspiracy theories, for  years he was a team-mate of Paul Clarke – brother of their current boss Steve.The pair even appeared on the same sticker in an edition of the annual Panini football album.All that’s prompted the Dundee Supporters’ Association to write to SFA head of referees’ committee chairman Willie Young and their head of refereeing, John Fleming, to question the sense behind having McLean taking games involving Kilmarnock.“Several of our members have contacted me to express their concerns over this and we think it’s only right to pass them on to the authorities,” said DSA chairman Kenny Ross.“And I do think there is reason to question the validity of this appointment when the referee so clearly has family connections to Kilmarnock.“If nothing  it puts him in a dficult position when you get a decision like Saturday’s.“I know that Steven McLean’s brother Brian played for Dundee United, Ross County and a few other clubs and he was not allowed to take charge of games involving teams he was at.“You think the same common sense approach could have been applied to his dad’s old team.”The fans also pointed out should the Killie player who ed to win the kick, Jordan Jones, be handed a two-game ban, that in itself could damage Dundee.The games he would miss would be against St Mirren and Hamilton, the two sides immediately above the Dark Blues at the foot of the Premiership.SFA chief executive Ian Maxwell was copied in when the letter was e-mailed and has promised a response will be given.

title: from dundee to india one womans story of three decades in the jute world
story: In her -year career in the jute industry she has produced everything from shrouds to hotpants.Today, Sandra Thompson-McGregor is the managing director of McGregor Balfour Textiles Ltd and her Dundee-based business has travelled across the globe.Sandra , from Broughty Ferry, was born in Kolkata, India, where her father James Davidson ran a thriving company which provided spare parts for jute factory machinery.She said: “I was sent to Beacon School for Girls in Stirling when I was very young and my family were living in India.“I used to go from Edinburgh to London, London to Amsterdam and Amsterdam to Kolkata – not bad for an eight-year-old.”The family moved to Dundee when Sandra was .She went to school at Grove Academy and later worked for the Education Department in Perth. But her le would change forever in  when her father died suddenly at his desk at the age of .Sandra, who spoke about her experiences during a recent talk at Stobsweell’s Boomerang Centre, said: “I went back to close the company with my mother – that was  years ago and I’m still trying to close McGregor Balfour.“My father worked with the company for  years and my grandfather was a jute mill manager out in India for  years. Maybe it was in my blood.”With no experience in the jute industry whatsoever, Sandra took the company over.She said: “At that time, a lot of companies had started to import jute and carpet yarn.“I thought, I can do that – I can speak the language out in India.“You just need to get them to send something on a boat and I’ll just have to sell it – it seemed simple to me until I started.”But le was to become more dficult.Many companies in the city stopped trading in jute and moved on to polypropylene in the mid s.Sandra said: “It was a very hard time in Dundee, a horrible time.”India’s jute workers later went on strike for six months and all work was put on hold.Sandra said: “I should have shut my doors too and made a run for it but my father would’ve been furious.”When the mills in India went back to work in the late s, Sandra was sent  massive containers of jute and it took her nearly two years to sell the lot.She said: “I was lying in my bed thinking, I have to shut now, I really have to shut.”One day Sandra came up with a plan – she decided to sell jute in a way no one ever had.Her many ventures included selling hats, bird boxes and shrouds made out of jute.She even sent a pair of tartan hotpants to Sean Connery.Her work eventually took her back to India.She said: “When my mother was out in India, all the millhouses were beautul.“Now they’re all rundown like The Best Exotic Marigold Hotel.“I went off to see one of the oldest family-run jute mills in Kolkata. The noise was absolutely deafening and the machinery was so old it went on fire – people were beating it out.“None of the men working the machines had shoes on or wore hearing protectors.”McGregor Balfour Textiles Ltd now mainly sells bags made out of jute.Sandra plans to retire soon. She said: “I’m very lucky that I love what I do.“I’ve had a lot of ups and downs in my le, but it’s all made me a stronger person.”

title: major traffic disruption on key dundee road to last another four weeks
story: Dundee motorists are set to face major traffic disruption on the A for the next four weeks.The project got under way on Sunday and is involving surfacing works across three locations between Claypotts junction and Elliot roundabout at Arbroath.Eddie Ross, operating company representative for BEAR Scotland, said the work was “essential to ensure the continued safe use of this stretch of the A”.Project bosses have tried to ensure there will be minimum disruption to road users with work taking place overnight between pm-am, Sunday-Friday.No work will take place on Friday and Saturday nights.During the operation sections of the A will be closed overnight with traffic erted locally.The majority of the project will take place using a mph convoy system to keep road users as well as motorists safe. Any ersions will be signed in advance.Bus services will follow ersion routes, with stops within the closure area unavailable during those periods.Phase one started between Upper Victoria and Ardestie interchange at Woodhill westbound, and Ardestie interchange bridge.Work being carried out by Tayside Contracts will mean traffic being erted south from Upper Victoria Interchange on to the C Carnoustie Road, the A Barry Bypass to the B Newbigging Road, the B Drumsturdy Road to C Ethiebeaton to West Grange Roundabout and on to the A.On Sunday and Tuesday nights works will start with the on-slip closure from pm, and a mph convoy working on the dual carriageway.On Monday and Wednesday nights the slip road will be re-opened, however a mph convoy system will remain in place.During the closures traffic will be erted to the B Newbigging Road, the B Drumsturdy Road to C Ethiebeaton, the West Grange Roundabout and on to the A.BEAR Scotland will be supervising work being carried out.Mr Ross said: “We will do everything possible to keep disruption to a minimum and have planned the project to take place overnight as well as avoiding the busier Friday and Saturday nights.”

title: shop owners expect to lose business when busy dundee street closes
story: Shops in a busy Broughty Ferry street are expecting to lose business when it is closed later this month.Gray Street, which has a level crossing for the main Dundee to Aberdeen railway, is to close overnight from Queen Street to Brook Street for Network Rail inspections.The closure will be from pm until am, Tuesday-Thursday, October -.However, it will then be closed from Friday October  for five working days to enable SSE Telecom work to be carried out although it will be open on the Saturday and Sunday to minimise disruption.The closure will allow engineers to complete duct cabling work as part of installing two new high voltage underground cables in Queen Street.There will be temporary traffic management systems and ersions in place while the work is carried out.Richard Henderson, one of the owners of jewellery store Matthew M Henderson, said the closure will affect them and complained there had been roadworks in the area recently.He said: “We have just had the railway station done, as well as the car park, which hasn’t really helped us at all as people can’t get parked.”Nicki McWilliam, manager of Iced Gems on Gray Street, said: “It will totally affect us. I would expect turnover to be down by % or more.”Khalid Farooq, manager of  Day News on Brook Street, said: “We will lose a lot of business because people can’t park. Most of our customers park directly outside.”Melanie Coleman, owner of Clementine of Broughty Ferry, said: “The closure could have a serious impact on my business because people often park on the street and just pop in to get what they need.”A spokeswoman for Scottish and Southern Electricity Networks said: “We would like to thank the local community for their patience as we carry out essential work as part of a customer connections project for Dundee City Council.“We will seek every practical step to minimise disruption and would like to apologise in advance for any inconvenience caused.”Councillor Craig Duncan pointed out that the street was one of the only level crossings which allowed people to get from the north of the railway line to the south.He said: “It will certainly be an inconvenience because of that.”

title: teles ninewells parking petition gets huge backing as 1500 call to freeze the fees
story: More than , of you have got behind the Tele’s campaign to freeze car parking charges at Ninewells Hospital.In just seven days, more than , readers have signed our petition which asks Indigo Infra Dundee Ltd to keep its car parking charges at existing levels until at least November next year. vw, px"  Scotland’s Health Secretary Jeane Freeman has also said she would like to abolish the charges.We launched our campaign following the announcement that parking fees at the hospital are to rise next month.Indigo Infra Dundee Ltd is locked in a -year contract with the health board to run all the car parks at Ninewells.Fees have risen over the years, meaning people who are attending the hospital through necessity are having to fork out more and more.The firm plans to raise the costs again, so day tickets and permits for staff will go up next month.Ms Freeman said: “I would like to be able to abolish car park charges at Ninewells – just as we have done in other hospitals across Scotland – but this is one of three car parks which are locked into long-term contracts that previous governments signed up to.“We have previously raised concerns about moves to increase these charges and called on the company involved to reconsider.“Charging to park at a hospital puts an unnecessary financial burden on families and those needing treatment.“In the funding packages we use for new health projects, we have made sure that charging for hospital car parking is prohibited.“We expect health boards to work to ensure that any charges in place are kept to a minimum and I expect all contracts to be kept under review to ensure best value for the public purse.”Among those who took the time to sign the petition was Elizabeth Malone, from Lochee.Mrs Malone said: “I think it’s disgraceful that they are putting the car parking charges up again.“It’s not right that nurses and doctors and visitors to patients should have to keep paying increased charges for parking their car.”Janette Doig, of Dunholm Road, said: “I signed the petition because I think it is very unfair that charges are to rise again.”David Irons, from Menzieshill, said: “I signed it for two reasons. It’s not fair that people have to pay to park at Ninewells when they don’t have to at other hospitals all over Scotland.“Also, we find it very dficult to park outside our own home because of hospital parking.“If people going to the hospital didn’t have to pay it would ease the parking situation for local residents.”You can support our campaign by signing our petition, which asks Indigo Infra Dundee Ltd to keep its car park charges at existing levels until at least November next year.PETITION: Sign to support the Tele#s campaign to Freeze the Fees at Ninewells Hospital" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp tele-calls-for-freeze-on-parking-fees-at-ninewells-hospital embed # secretiOgVgGLEXJ" data-secret"iOgVgGLEXJ" width"" "" title"#PETITION: Sign to support the Tele#s campaign to Freeze the Fees at Ninewells Hospital# # Evening " frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"

title: scotland-v-portugal-five-things-we-learned
story: Sting through the wreckage to find the positives from a defeat to what is essentially Portugalrsquos reserves is not a fun way to partake of a Sunday evening. In fairness to Alex McLeishrsquos side there were some elements to take from the performance in the opening half which seemed far more cohesive that the shambles that was the defeat in Israel last Thursday night. Still, though, whether you look at the game through the most optimistic glasses, the fact is that even at this ridiculously early stage, McLeish has the look of a manager who is already under tremendous pressure. The manner of the three goals shipped to Portugal had the hallmark of team already weary from being on the same familiar treadmill. For all the rare glimpses that suggest Scotland might be able to build something, the overall impression gleaned from watching McLeishrsquos side is that this is a team in absolute decline.
